The greatest glory in living lies not in never falling, but in rising every time we fall.

- Nelson Mandela

Welcome!

Welcome to our mental health website! This site is designed to help those with mental health concerns, as well as for those who care for them. We provide information on symptoms, tips, and emergency contacts. We hope you find the information here helpful and informative. Remember, it's important to reach out for support if you or someone you know is experiencing any of these symptoms. Mental health professionals can provide the necessary help and guidance.

Message Yourself

First, take a moment to check in with yourself. How are you feeling today? What's on your mind? One strategy to help manage your mental health is to write down your thoughts and feelings. This can help you process your emotions and gain a better understanding of your mental state. You can also use this as an opportunity to send yourself a positive message. Talk to yourself as you would talk to a friend. Be encouraging and positive. Remember, it's important to be kind to yourself and practice self-care. You are not alone. We are here to support you.

Click the button below to open a pop up window to send yourtself a message!

Disclaimer

The contents of this site may be triggering for some visitors. The sections which follow include descriptions of symptoms which could indicate mental health conditions as well as advice on how to manage them.

If you or anyone you are caring is experiencing a mental health crisis, please contact one of the services via the following page

Symptoms

If you have any signs or symptoms of a mental illness, see your primary care provider or a mental health professional. Most mental illnesses don't improve on their own, and if untreated, a mental illness may get worse over time and cause serious problems.

These are a sample of 4 kinds of symptoms you may witness within yourself or those around you. They are not an exhaustive list and you are encouraged to visit the sites in the external pages section to view a wider selection.

It's important to reach out for support if you or someone you know is experiencing any of these symptoms. Mental health professionals can provide the necessary help and guidance.

Anxiety

Having anxious thoughts or beliefs that are hard to control, or worrying about the past or future. Having a racing or pounding heartbeat, dizziness, shortness of breath, unexplained aches and pains, sweating, trembling, or shaking.

Low Mood / Depression

Persistent sadness, loss of interest in activities, fatigue, changes in sleep and appetite, difficulty concentrating, feelings of worthlessness, and thoughts of death or self-harm.

Stress

Symptoms of stress include irritability, fatigue, headaches, muscle tension, sleep disturbances, difficulty concentrating, changes in appetite, and increased heart rate. Chronic stress can lead to more severe health issues if not managed properly.

Isolation

Isolating oneself from others can be a symptom of several mental health conditions, including:

  • Depression
  • Anxiety
  • PTSD
  • Social Anxiety Disorder

Mental Health Tips

Below are some tips to help you manage your mental health. Remember, it's important to reach out for support if you or someone you know is experiencing any of these symptoms. Mental health professionals can provide the necessary help and guidance. A list of external pages is available at the bottom of the screen.

Reframe unhelpful thoughts

The way we think, feel and behave are linked. Sometimes we develop patterns of thoughts or behaviours that are unhelpful so recognising them, and taking steps to think about things differently, can improve your mental health and wellbeing.

Be in the present

If we take time to be aware of ourselves and be in the present moment, noticing our own thoughts and feelings, and the world around us, we can gain a better perspective. Sometimes this is known as being more mindful.

Connect with others

Spending quality time with friends or family, talking to someone about how we are feeling or finding ways to help other people can all help stop you from feeling lonely and improve your mental health and wellbeing.

Get good sleep

Good sleep is essential for mental health as it regulates emotions, boosts cognitive function, and reduces stress. Quality rest enhances brain resilience, improving overall well-being and coping abilities.

External Pages

Below are links to external pages which can provide further information and support for mental health concerns. Remember, it's important to reach out for support if you or someone you know is experiencing any of these symptoms. Mental health professionals can provide the necessary help and guidance.

Whilst these sites are local to Birmingham and the West Midlands, many more are available nationally.

Birmingham Mental Health and Wellbeing Hub

Provides support for mental health through recovery courses, therapeutic activities, and peer support in Birmingham and Solihull.

Birmingham Mind

Provides support for mental health through community services, personal support, and training in Birmingham.

BSMHFT

Provides mental health services for all ages, including inpatient, community, and specialist care in Birmingham and Solihull.

Samaritans

Provides emotional support to those in distress, 24/7, through a helpline, preventing crises and promoting mental well-being.
